title: Flatto: Building in Public the App for Shared Flats
subtitle: Testing the limits of AI-assisted development through vibe coding
metaTitle: **Flatto – Building an App for Shared Flats with AI

text.content: Copilot, Cursor, ChatGPT, Perplexity, Claude, Gemini, Windsurf… we keep hearing and reading these names everywhere. Everyone’s talking about

text.content: — whether they’re developers or not. We’re seeing people launch apps and websites built almost entirely by AI, and sometimes even seeing those same projects get hacked soon after.

text.content: who develops complete projects for clients, I can’t help but wonder how some manage to ship full apps so quickly and immediately jump into the next one. And as a junior developer, it’s natural to feel both curious and a bit uneasy about what this AI-driven future means. If development is heading in that direction, then better start mastering it now, right?

text.content: vibe coding? The term was coined in February 2025 by Andrej Karpathy on X (Twitter). He defines it very specifically — in vibe coding, there’s no actual coding at all. You “forget that the code even exists.”

rich_text.plain_text: vibe coding? The term was coined in February 2025 by Andrej Karpathy on X (Twitter). He defines it very specifically — in vibe coding, there’s no actual coding at all. You “forget that the code even exists.”

text.content: So, vibe coding doesn’t involve touching the code at all. Quite the opposite, actually. The vibe coder interacts exclusively with the LLM. They don’t even review the code it generates. If it works, it’s accepted as-is. If it doesn’t, the LLM is asked to improve it.

rich_text.plain_text: So, vibe coding doesn’t involve touching the code at all. Quite the opposite, actually. The vibe coder interacts exclusively with the LLM. They don’t even review the code it generates. If it works, it’s accepted as-is. If it doesn’t, the LLM is asked to improve it.

text.content: That’s my go-to formula. Then, depending on what I’m building, I adjust it with extra information. After reading blogs, watching several videos on prompting techniques, and experimenting a lot, these are the tips and patterns that consistently give me the best results:

rich_text.plain_text: That’s my go-to formula. Then, depending on what I’m building, I adjust it with extra information. After reading blogs, watching several videos on prompting techniques, and experimenting a lot, these are the tips and patterns that consistently give me the best results:

text.content: Always explain the bigger picture of what you’re building.

rich_text.plain_text: Always explain the bigger picture of what you’re building.

text.content: Including context files makes a massive difference — it helps the model focus and reduces hallucinations.

rich_text.plain_text: Including context files makes a massive difference — it helps the model focus and reduces hallucinations.

text.content: Describe the desired behavior, not the implementation.

rich_text.plain_text: Describe the desired behavior, not the implementation.

text.content: (I wish I remembered who suggested this!) It’s a game changer! The model keeps iterating until everything works, often without extra input.

rich_text.plain_text: (I wish I remembered who suggested this!) It’s a game changer! The model keeps iterating until everything works, often without extra input.

text.content: Don’t dive straight into coding. Ask the model to outline a plan first — it leads to cleaner, more detailed implementations and self-generated to-do lists.

rich_text.plain_text: Don’t dive straight into coding. Ask the model to outline a plan first — it leads to cleaner, more detailed implementations and self-generated to-do lists.

text.content: Learning when to use each of these tricks (or combine them) is key to getting the best results.

rich_text.plain_text: Learning when to use each of these tricks (or combine them) is key to getting the best results.

text.content: Right now, this workflow works best for me, though it’s constantly evolving. If you have any tips or think any of these patterns could be improved, I’d love to hear from you!

text.content: And to keep things short (and because, let’s be honest, you’d get bored otherwise), I won’t share my full prompts here — but I’ll quote some important parts. Also, please don’t judge my prompts; I text AI like using the same language as if I text a friend 😒😂

text.content: With the motivation to test the limits and capabilities of AI —and with my chosen tech stack ready— I decided to take an idea from my notebook and bring it to life, from start to finish (yes, including release). That’s how

rich_text.plain_text: With the motivation to test the limits and capabilities of AI —and with my chosen tech stack ready— I decided to take an idea from my notebook and bring it to life, from start to finish (yes, including release). That’s how

text.content: Having lived in shared apartments for over ten years, I know firsthand how chaotic things can get. Whose turn is it to clean? Did we take out the trash? What essentials do we need to buy? These questions pop up constantly, and the result is always the same: endless WhatsApp messages, repeated and repeated and repeated and repeated... If something’s repetitive, there’s an app for it.

rich_text.plain_text: Having lived in shared apartments for over ten years, I know firsthand how chaotic things can get. Whose turn is it to clean? Did we take out the trash? What essentials do we need to buy? These questions pop up constantly, and the result is always the same: endless WhatsApp messages, repeated and repeated and repeated and repeated... If something’s repetitive, there’s an app for it.

But before getting there, I need to break things down and analyze the complexity of each feature—especially since I’m letting AI handle the coding.

text.content: The first core feature is the

rich_text.plain_text: The first core feature is the

text.content: . Its basic functionality is simple: tenants add items that are needed in the flat and mark them as bought once they’re purchased. It’s a classic beginner project. The only twist is the “shared” part, which can be solved easily using a cloud database that all tenants can access.

rich_text.plain_text: . Its basic functionality is simple: tenants add items that are needed in the flat and mark them as bought once they’re purchased. It’s a classic beginner project. The only twist is the “shared” part, which can be solved easily using a cloud database that all tenants can access.

text.content: Once that’s in place, the feature can evolve. For example, users could enter the price of each item, enabling graphs and statistics showing how much each person spends. But we’ll explore that later.

rich_text.plain_text: Once that’s in place, the feature can evolve. For example, users could enter the price of each item, enabling graphs and statistics showing how much each person spends. But we’ll explore that later.

text.content: . It sounds simple at first —just assign chores and track who cleans what— but reality gets complicated fast. Every apartment handles cleaning differently. Some clean weekly, others biweekly (or… whenever the chaos demands it 😅). There are also tasks like taking out the trash on specific days, which might not fall to the same person each time.

rich_text.plain_text: . It sounds simple at first —just assign chores and track who cleans what— but reality gets complicated fast. Every apartment handles cleaning differently. Some clean weekly, others biweekly (or… whenever the chaos demands it 😅). There are also tasks like taking out the trash on specific days, which might not fall to the same person each time.

text.content: And that’s not all. In shared flats, people come and go —vacations, trips home, visits to family—sometimes long enough to skip several cleaning turns. All of that needs to be accounted for.

rich_text.plain_text: And that’s not all. In shared flats, people come and go —vacations, trips home, visits to family—sometimes long enough to skip several cleaning turns. All of that needs to be accounted for.

text.content: There’s more to it, of course. Not all chores take the same amount of effort, so that needs to be considered when assigning them. The cleaning schedule can’t just rotate tasks blindly — it needs a weighted algorithm that balances the workload fairly among all tenants.

rich_text.plain_text: There’s more to it, of course. Not all chores take the same amount of effort, so that needs to be considered when assigning them. The cleaning schedule can’t just rotate tasks blindly — it needs a weighted algorithm that balances the workload fairly among all tenants.

text.content: this project, things get interesting. These requirements demand a scalable architecture and careful handling of edge cases —areas where AI tends to struggle. So yes, this will be a challenge. I have no idea how far I’ll get toward a release-ready app using this approach, but I’m about to find out.

text.content: When it comes to developing something new, whether it’s a major feature or a simple dialog, AI performs impressively. With the right prompt, it can deliver fast, clean, and well-structured code. However, as

rich_text.plain_text: When it comes to developing something new, whether it’s a major feature or a simple dialog, AI performs impressively. With the right prompt, it can deliver fast, clean, and well-structured code. However, as

text.content: “vibe coding is all fun and games until you have to vibe debug.”

rich_text.plain_text: “vibe coding is all fun and games until you have to vibe debug.”

text.content: You have to describe the bug countless times, tell it what not to do, and sometimes, if you're lucky, you manage to fix it. I've tried everything: describing the bug behavior, pointing to the specific code section, explaining the underlying software principle, copying errors and logs... But what worked best? Simply finding and fixing the bug myself.

rich_text.plain_text: You have to describe the bug countless times, tell it what not to do, and sometimes, if you're lucky, you manage to fix it. I've tried everything: describing the bug behavior, pointing to the specific code section, explaining the underlying software principle, copying errors and logs... But what worked best? Simply finding and fixing the bug myself.

text.content: In the time it takes to write prompts and go through multiple iterations, I could have debugged it manually. And that's assuming AI can actually fix it. Sometimes I just have to abandon the approach entirely. I haven't found an effective way to write prompts for debugging. If you know any tips, please share!

rich_text.plain_text: In the time it takes to write prompts and go through multiple iterations, I could have debugged it manually. And that's assuming AI can actually fix it. Sometimes I just have to abandon the approach entirely. I haven't found an effective way to write prompts for debugging. If you know any tips, please share!

text.content: So for my own sanity, I decided that I won't be purely "vibe coding". I'll have to write code myself when needed.

text.content: summarize what I've learned during this project, how I view AI after attempting to fully vibe code with it, and whether this experience will change my development process going forward.

rich_text.plain_text: summarize what I've learned during this project, how I view AI after attempting to fully vibe code with it, and whether this experience will change my development process going forward.

text.content: Initially, I used AI for everything and development progressed incredibly quickly. I created a functional version of the app in a single weekend. While extremely simple, it worked and served its purpose. However, my main goal with this project is to build an app ready for release, and it was far from that stage.

rich_text.plain_text: Initially, I used AI for everything and development progressed incredibly quickly. I created a functional version of the app in a single weekend. While extremely simple, it worked and served its purpose. However, my main goal with this project is to build an app ready for release, and it was far from that stage.

text.content: If I want this app to earn its place in the marketplace, I need to add essential features, improve existing ones, handle edge cases, and create a production environment. That's simply too much work for AI alone.

rich_text.plain_text: If I want this app to earn its place in the marketplace, I need to add essential features, improve existing ones, handle edge cases, and create a production environment. That's simply too much work for AI alone.

text.content: So I have to admit that I cannot build this entire project through vibe coding. The limitation I've discovered is vibe debugging. Currently, the vibe coding experience is great—fun and efficient. But until vibe debugging improves significantly, it's not practical to fully vibe code an app all the way to release.

rich_text.plain_text: So I have to admit that I cannot build this entire project through vibe coding. The limitation I've discovered is vibe debugging. Currently, the vibe coding experience is great—fun and efficient. But until vibe debugging improves significantly, it's not practical to fully vibe code an app all the way to release.

text.content: With the progress I’ve made in this experiment, I’ve learned exactly where AI shines and where it struggles. I now know when to rely on a model and when it’s faster to just code things myself. Some tasks simply take longer to explain than to do, so if it’s too complicated to describe, just build it yourself.

rich_text.plain_text: With the progress I’ve made in this experiment, I’ve learned exactly where AI shines and where it struggles. I now know when to rely on a model and when it’s faster to just code things myself. Some tasks simply take longer to explain than to do, so if it’s too complicated to describe, just build it yourself.

text.content: (Although, don’t apply that rule to life. There, if it’s too hard to explain, it’s probably a bad idea 😬).
